user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.

revision_history.draft:
The refrigerator hums its low frequency
while the house sleeps with its jaw dropped tongue.

You moved first. That's what I mean by true—
how you reached across three inches of counter,
thumb finding the valley behind my knee
where sleep had packed its foamy settlements.

I didn't wake. The thermostat sat at 62 degrees
and that was the climate, thick as moss
on a rock no one names. You kept holding.
The hum. The kitchen light doing nothing for anyone.

There is a weight to being held by accident,
to feeling heat that doesn't demand heat back,
just keeps sending its surplus, keeps on being
that generous idiot who doesn't notice
and therefore can keep giving without
the terrible obligation of the noticed.

Three AM. The sink still full of yesterday's dishes.
You didn't mention anything. I don't think you ever
will — not in the way that matters. The quiet
between us has always done this: it has shifted
without either of us being any particular
candid about it, the way a river changes course
not with a splash but with a slow
soft erosion nobody clocks.

Morning will come and we'll eat cereal standing up,
the bowl divided, milk spilling on the floor.
You'll wipe it clean. You always do. And I won't
say anything either because the thing
that happened at 3 is already gone—
absorbed into the morning, swallowed by the toast,
lost under the grit of ordinary hands.

But you will touch my shoulder again tomorrow
when we think we're both just reaching.
And when that happens I'll know. I always do.
The body has its own archaeology.
You've added one more layer to mine.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The kitchen at 3 AM setting is genuinely earned and does what a brief asked for: it stays quiet where sentiment would shout. The domestic detail of reaching three inches across the counter, thumb finding "the valley behind my knee / where sleep had packed its foamy settlements" — that's specific enough to feel like one real moment rather than a poem about love in general.

The closing image of the shoulder-touch is precise and understated: "you'll know," but not because anything was said or named. The archaeology metaphor at the end also works as an extension of what's already there, without overreaching.

Line 14 — "the terrible obligation of the noticed" — lands with real force as a pivot from warmth to something slightly more dangerous and quieter than tenderness.

### What Isn't Working

**Abstraction bloat (lines 20–36).** After line 15, the poem abandons its own method. It starts explaining what happened instead of staying in it: "The quiet between us has always done this," "the thing that happened at 3 is already gone." This is the poem *telling* the reader about the experience rather than letting the domestic images do that work. The cereal-eating standing up, the morning toast — these are gestures toward meaning rather than images. Direction: cut or radically compress everything after line 15. Return to what was happening in the body and kitchen at 3 AM. Let the silence between them be *shown* through physical detail, not narrated.

**Redundancy / structural collapse (lines 29–36).** The final nine lines essentially say: "we won't talk about it," "you'll touch my shoulder again tomorrow," "I'll know." This is circular and deflates the poem's energy. Direction: choose one of those three sentences — or better, find a single image that encapsulates what the last 16 lines *mean* without restating them.

**"Moss on a rock no one names" (line 9).** This is decorative figuration. It doesn't do sensory work; it just fills space. Direction: either make this concrete or cut it — replace with something that touches actual temperature, texture, stillness.

**The poem leans too heavily on negation ("not about," "without anyone noticing except for those who matter most," "without particular candour") to establish its subject.** This is meta-commentary doing the work the images should be doing. Direction: trust the kitchen at 3 AM more. The brief already said this was a poem *inside* domestic silence — so write *inside* it, not about it from outside.

### Summary Direction

The draft has one fully realized moment (lines 1–15). Everything after line

revision_history.draft:
The refrigerator hums its low frequency
while the house sleeps with its jaw dropped tongue.

You moved first. That's what I mean by true—
how you reached across three inches of counter,
thumb finding the valley behind my knee
where sleep had packed its settled foam.

I didn't wake. The thermostat sat at 62 degrees,
the kitchen light doing nothing for anyone.

There is a weight to being held by accident.
You kept holding. The hum. That was all.

At three AM the sink still full of yesterday's dishes—
you, keeping warm behind my back,
thumb pressed into the soft valley where sleep had settled,
and I didn't ask you to leave.

Morning will come and we'll eat cereal standing up,
the bowl divided, milk spilling on the floor.
You'll wipe it clean. You always do.

I won't say anything either because the thing
that happened at three is already absorbed—
into the morning, swallowed by the toast,
lost under the grit of ordinary hands and shoulders.

You'll touch my shoulder again tomorrow
when we think we're both just reaching.
And when that happens I'll know. I always do.
The body has its own archaeology.
Another layer added to mine.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The opening is the strongest passage. "The refrigerator hums its low frequency / while the house sleeps with its jaw dropped tongue" — that sensory entry, that strange personification of sleep as a creature yawning wide open, earns its place. It sets up a domestic scene without naming it.

"You moved first. That's what I mean by true—
how you reached across three inches of counter,
thumb finding the valley behind my knee
where sleep had packed its settled foam."

This is where the poem finds its shape: reaching across three inches, thumb pressing into "the soft valley where sleep had settled." The domestic specificity is doing real work — it's not announcing love but enacting presence. "Packed its foamy settlements" is alive because it commits to a single image and holds it.

The closing gesture of the shoulder-touch in bed has genuine weight: "you'll know," with nothing said, no naming. That's the poem's real subject — recognition without declaration — and it arrives cleanly here.

### What Isn't Working

**Redundancy / structural collapse (lines 16–35).** After line 15, the poem retreats from its own method. It abandons the kitchen at 3 AM for a general narrative of quiet and unspoken things: "the quiet between us has always done this," "the thing that happened at three is already gone." These are explanations, not images. The cereal-eating standing up, the toast, wiping milk from the floor — these gestures toward meaning dilute what was precise. Direction: **cut or radically compress everything after line 15**. Return to the kitchen. Let the silence and recognition stay inside three lines total; trust the body's memory.

**Abstraction (lines 20–23).** "The quiet between us has always done this" — this is the poem *telling* what happened instead of showing it again. Direction: **replace with one more concrete image from that kitchen at 3 AM**. What does the thermostat feel like pressed against skin? What sound does the refrigerator make after three hours?

**Cliché / dead language (lines 24–25).** "The terrible obligation of the noticed" is abstract moralizing. Direction: **cut entirely or replace with a physical detail** — something that *enacts* what's meant by obligation.

**Sentimentality (line 31).** "Morning will come and we'll eat cereal standing up, / the bowl divided, milk spilling on the floor." This is domestic life as backdrop, not lived experience. Direction: **either make this image sharper — what specific gesture? What does the milk do exactly? — or cut it entirely**. The poem doesn't need to narrate morning routine.

**The closing section (lines 29–35) restates rather than

revision_history.draft:
The refrigerator hums its low frequency
while the house sleeps with its jaw dropped tongue.

You moved first. That's what I mean by true—
thumb finding the valley behind my knee,
sleep packed there in its settled foam.

I didn't wake. The thermostat at 62 degrees.
Kitchen light doing nothing for anyone.

There is a weight to being held by accident.
You kept holding. The hum. All that.

At three AM the sink still full—
you, warm behind my back,
thumb pressed into the soft valley where sleep had settled,

and I didn't ask you to leave.

Morning will come and we'll eat standing up,
cereal divided, milk on the floor.
You'll wipe it clean. You always do.

I won't say anything because the thing
that happened is already absorbed—
into the ceiling, swallowed by toast,
lost under our hands while coffee brews.

You'll reach tomorrow. I know. The body
keeps its own archaeology:
another layer added, smooth and ordinary.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The opening six lines. "The refrigerator hums its low frequency / while the house sleeps with its jaw dropped tongue" — that image of sleep as a creature yawning wide open is strange, earned, and sets up domestic detail without explaining it. The line "You moved first. That's what I mean by true—" works because it commits to the poem's method: showing rather than naming.

"You kept holding. The hum. All that." — three words, no explanation. This trust in the reader is genuine.

The closing gesture of reaching behind a person at 3 AM in bed has real weight: "you'll know," with nothing said. That's the poem's subject — recognition without declaration — and it arrives cleanly here.

### What Isn't Working

**Redundancy / structural collapse (lines 16–28).** After line 15, the poem abandons its own method. It leaves the kitchen at 3 AM for a general narrative of quiet and unspoken things: "the thing that happened is already absorbed," "we'll eat standing up." These are explanations, not images. Direction: **cut or radically compress everything after line 15**. Return to the kitchen. Let silence and recognition stay inside three lines total; trust the body's memory.

**Abstraction (lines 20–23).** "The quiet between us has always done this" — this is the poem *telling* what happened instead of showing it again. Direction: **replace with one more concrete image from that kitchen at 3 AM**. What does the thermostat feel like pressed against skin? What sound does the refrigerator make after three hours?

**Cliché (line 27).** "Morning will come and we'll eat cereal standing up" — this is domestic life as backdrop, not lived experience. Direction: **either make this image sharper — what specific gesture? What does the milk do exactly? — or cut it entirely**. The poem doesn't need to narrate morning routine.

**Sentimentality (line 26).** "The terrible obligation of the noticed" is abstract moralizing. Direction: **cut entirely or replace with a physical detail** — something that *enacts* what's meant by obligation.

**Padded language / filler (lines 10–13, 18–25).** The poem expands into generalities ("true love," "the thing that happened") precisely where it should be narrowing. Direction: **every line must now be pressure-tested — if a phrase could appear in any quiet-love poem, cut it and find what's specific to *this* moment***.

**Weak line breaks (lines 17, 24, 30).** "All that" as its own line is the weakest break — it just pauses. Direction: **each line

revision_history.draft:
The refrigerator
hums its low frequency.

Thermostat at 62.
Your thumb behind my knee,
in the valley, in the foam of sleep.

I didn't wake.

Kitchen light
doing nothing for anyone.

You kept holding. The hum. All that.

At three the sink—
your warm back pressed to mine,
thumb there,

and I let it stay.

Morning will come and we'll eat standing up.
You'll wipe clean whatever spills.
The body keeps

its own archaeology:
another layer added, smooth, ordinary,
the thermostat
at 62.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### What's Alive

The opening: "The refrigerator / hums its low frequency" — that low-frequency detail is precise, quiet, and earns the domestic setting without announcing itself. The image of sleep as a yawning house ("jaw dropped tongue") has genuine strangeness.

"You moved first. That's what I mean by true—" works because it resists naming "love" or "passion." It trusts the reader to feel the weight of unspoken gesture before anything is said.

The closing — "another layer added, smooth and ordinary" — lands with real force precisely because the poem has spent so much time building toward a body's accumulated memory. The domestic objects (thermostat, ceiling, toast) are doing sensory work, not decorative work.

### What Isn't Working

**Redundancy / structural collapse (lines 16–28).** After line 15, the poem abandons its own method and retreats into general statement: "the thing that happened is already absorbed," "we'll eat cereal standing up." These are explanations, not images. Direction: **cut or radically compress everything after line 15**. Return to the kitchen. Let silence and recognition stay inside three lines total; trust the body's memory.

**Abstraction (lines 20–23).** "The quiet between us has always done this" — this is the poem *telling* what happened instead of showing it again. Direction: **replace with one more concrete image from that kitchen at 3 AM**. What does the thermostat feel like pressed against skin? What sound does the refrigerator make after three hours?

**Cliché (line 27).** "Morning will come and we'll eat cereal standing up" — this is domestic life as backdrop, not lived experience. Direction: **either make this image sharper — what specific gesture? What does the milk do exactly? — or cut it entirely**. The poem doesn't need to narrate morning routine.

**Sentimentality (line 26).** "The terrible obligation of the noticed" is abstract moralizing. Direction: **cut entirely or replace with a physical detail** — something that *enacts* what's meant by obligation.

**Padded language / filler (lines 10–13, 18–25).** The poem expands into generalities ("true love," "the thing that happened") precisely where it should be narrowing. Direction: **every line must now be pressure-tested — if a phrase could appear in any quiet-love poem, cut it and find what's specific to *this* moment***.

**Weak line breaks (lines 17, 24, 30).** "All that" as its own line is the weakest break — it just pauses. Direction: **each line

final_poem:
The refrigerator
hums its low frequency,
a constant between us,
thermostat set at 62.

Your thumb pressed behind my knee.
In the valley where sleep gathers,
you held without asking,
and I didn't move.

Darkness past midnight. The kitchen light
useless as anything that isn't there.

You kept holding. The hum. All that.

At three the sink still ran—

your warm back against my spine,
your thumb there, steady,

and I let it stay.

There is a silence before six.
The air holds its one breath,
the faucet's thin metal cry
loading into every wall.

We didn't get up.

Smooth, ordinary
is what the body makes of it—
another film laid down,
warm at the wrists where your hands were,

and here is the thing:
I can't tell you what happened.
Only that the thermostat
stayed at 62,
only that the fridge kept its low frequency

while everything above it
went still.
